thread.title: Food hall trend coming Downtown with plan for Oxford Market
thread.title_full: Food hall trend coming Downtown with plan for Oxford Market

author: Mark Belko / Pittsburgh Post-Gazette
title: Food hall trend coming Downtown with plan for Oxford Market
text:
Food hall trend coming Downtown with plan for Oxford Market January 26, 2017 12:56 PM Nate Guidry/Post-Gazette A pedestrian walks past One Oxford Centre on Grant Street in May. By Mark Belko / Pittsburgh Post-Gazette 
Cities like New York and Chicago have been bubbling with trendy food halls featuring specialty chefs, sit-down restaurants, and vendors. Now one is coming to Downtown Pittsburgh. 
Oxford Market — a marketplace that will offer restaurants, chef demonstrations, wine tastings and other food options — is expected to open in One Oxford Centre this summer. 
San Francisco-based Shorenstein Properties LLC, the new owner of the 45-story Grant Street skyscraper, has completed an agreement with Eurest, a $1.4 billion food and vending division of Compass Group North America, to bring the concept to Downtown. 
The 12,000-square-foot food hall will be located in the lower level of the building, taking up space formerly occupied by Easy Street restaurant, which has closed, and management offices. The food hall will use Oxford's outdoor plaza during warmer weather. 
It is expected to include restaurants featuring international fare, including Mexican and Italian offerings, as well as specialty concepts focused on salads and healthy meal options. 
The food hall also will be home to Create Exhibition, a space where visitors will have access to chef demonstrations, wine tastings and other events. Eurest plans to partner with a number of popular Pittsburgh restaurants and celebrity chefs as part of the endeavor. 
Shorenstein sees the food hall as catering to Downtown residents, in addition to office workers and visitors to the city. 
"Oxford Market will offer residents and office tenants in Downtown Pittsburgh a space to gather for lunch, dinner or a fun night out," said Christopher Caltabiano, Shorenstein's senior vice president of asset management. "We're very pleased with the progress that has been made at One Oxford Centre and look forward to continuing to enhance the building's iconic status as part of Pittsburgh's skyline." 
Shorenstein representatives toured more than a dozen food halls in New York and Chicago in search of the best concept for Pittsburgh. 
In a statement, Jeremy Waldrup, president and CEO of the Pittsburgh Downtown Partnership, said food halls have been expanding in major markets around the country. 
"Shorenstein's vision for this project is bringing in new amenities that will benefit office workers and our growing residential community while supporting Pittsburgh's innovative and evolving restaurant scene," he said. 
Oxford Market will be part of $50 million in renovations that Shorenstein, a real estate investment company, is making to the property. Au Bon Pain and a sushi restaurant are expected to remain in the lower level of the building. 
Based in Charlotte, N.C., Compass Group North America is a leading food service management and support services company that posted $14.5 billion in revenues in 2015. It is part of United Kingdom-based Compass Group PLC.
